p: Tradeoffs are an issue in any biomarker discovery or validation effort; they arise between maximizing the quantity versus the quality of the data, in real-world versus standardized situations, enabling cost-efficient yet safe measurements. As described in Section 2, in any respiratory disease epidemic, and specifically in case of COVID-19, we suggest that with highest priority, swabs and dried blood shall be done based on a simple set of rules, observing minimum standards, to limit the influence of systematic confounders as well as random influences, while still reflecting the real-world situation. Then, if there is sufficient signal for learning biomarkers, these can be expected to generalize well. A specific tradeoff are biosafety issues, see supplement 1.
